options: Apologise to the bed manager, cancel the CT scan and discharge Mr Pye

Explain to the bed manager that if bowel obstruction is present, Mr Pye will require medical management and cannot be sent home. Handover to the on-call team to review the CT scan and discharge Mr Pye if they have no concerns
Apologise to the bed manager. Explain that Mr Pye will not be going home today. A decision will be made tomorrow after reviewing the scan results
Ask the bed manager to contact your consultant to discuss the discharge
Scold the bed manager for not prioritising Mr Pye's safety
questions:
You are the oncology F2. Mr Pye is ready for discharge, with community palliative care input whilst at home. He has a suspected 3-6 month survival. Just before discharge, you notice Mr Pye has a distended abdomen. Your registrar asks you to order an CT abdomen, to exclude bowel obstruction. It is 5pm and you have only just ordered the CT.

The bed manager calls and says that Mr Pye needs to be discharged because his bed has been allocated to another patient. She says that the CT abdomen is unnecessary since the patient is palliative.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most appropriate action is (B), to explain that Mr Pye requires the CT scan and will require management if bowel obstruction is found. If bowel obstruction is not present he can be discharged by the on-call team to free the bed for the new patient. It is dangerous to send Mr Pye home with bowel obstruction as he may develop a perforation or re-present to hospital with vomiting. Despite the fact that he is for palliative care, he has a prognosis of 3-6 months therefore is not expected to deteriorate in the near future.

Option (C), delaying discharge until tomorrow also ensures Mr Pye's safety. However, it is better to discharge Mr Pye if he is well, since there is another patient requiring the bed. Additionally the longer Mr Pye unnecessarily stays in hospital, the more likely he is to develop further complications, such as a hospital acquired pneumonia.

Option (D), asking the bed manager to discuss the issue with your consultant, is the next most appropriate action. Once again this will ensure patient safety. However, it is preferable to try to explain to the bed manager yourself first before involving your consultant.

Option (E) is unprofessional. It is not your job to scold the bed manager. However it is better than option (A), cancelling the scan and discharging My Pye, which risks patient safety.

options: Prescribe fluids on your return tomorrow morning
Drive back and prescribe it yourself
Send a text message to your colleague and ask him to prescribe the fluids
Assume the nurse will ask another doctor

questions:
You are the surgical junior doctor on your way home from a long and busy shift. During your drive home, you remember that a nurse asked you to prescribe maintenance IV fluids for a stable gentleman awaiting a residential home placement. You are now half an hour away from the hospital. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
Despite the fact that the stem implies a well patient, there could be many reasons why he would be requiring IV fluids and from this we should assume that the request is one that should be urgently acted upon. However, you are far away from work and there will be someone else there able to do so. Hence the best option would be to ring the ward and ask the doctor there to prescribe the fluids. By sending a text you risk it not being read and the fluids not being prescribed until it is too late, so the better option, although inconvenient, would be to drive back. Answers A and D do not convey the urgency of the situation. It is however better to prescribe them the next morning than assume that the nurse will ask someone else.

title: GMC: Prescribing and managing medicines and devices content
body:
Good Practice in Prescribing Medicines was published in 2008. A link is provided to the full guidance, below is only selected highlights:

Principles of prescribing
  • doctors with full registration may prescribe all medicines, but not those drugs in Schedule 1 of the Misuse of Drugs Regulations 2001
  • you should only prescribe drugs to meet identified needs of patients and never for your own convenience or simply because patients demand them
  • avoid treating yourself and those close to you

Keeping up to date and prescribing in patients' best interests
  • the guidelines make specific mention of the BNF, NICE and SIGN
  • you should inform the Committee on the Safety of Medicines of adverse reactions to medicines reported by your patients in accordance with the Yellow Card Scheme
  • if you prescribe at the recommendation of a nurse or other healthcare professional who does not have prescribing rights, you must be satisfied that the prescription is appropriate for the patient concerned and that the professional is competent to have recommended the treatment

Doctors' interests in pharmacies
  • you should ensure that your patients have access to information about your own and (where known) your employers' financial or commercial interests in any pharmacy they are likely to use

Prescribing controlled drugs for yourself or someone close to you
  • doctors should, wherever possible, avoid treating themselves or anyone with whom they have a close personal relationship and should be registered with a GP outside their family
  • you should not prescribe a controlled drug for yourself or someone close to you unless no other person with the legal right to prescribe is available to assess the patient's clinical condition and to prescribe without a delay which would put the patient's life or health at risk, or cause the patient unacceptable pain, and that treatment is immediately necessary to save life, avoid serious deterioration in the patient's health or alleviate otherwise uncontrollable pain

Remote prescribing via telephone, email, fax, video link or a website
  • this is supported in the guidelines with obvious caveats
  • if you are 'not providing continuing care for the patient', for example doing out-of-hours the guidelines recommend giving an explanation to the patient of the processes involved in remote consultations and giving your name and GMC number to the patient

questions:
You are a junior doctor in general surgery. An FY2 colleague has been behaving strangely at work for the past two weeks, abandoning the ward without informing anyone and not completing tasks fully. This is quite out of character for him, but you have heard in passing that there are some issues going on at home.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes: The most appropriate response would be to offer some support to your colleague confidentially and suggest they inform their clinical supervisor in the first instance. Then, the most immediately helpful option is to offer to help with their jobs. Doing nothing is unsupportive and may compromise patient care. The doctor may need to take the day off but this would not be the first option.

title: GMC: Good medical practice - Communication, partnership and teamwork
body:
Communication, partnership and teamwork form one of the four domains listed in the Good Medical Practice. This domain focuses on the standards expected of doctors in areas such as communication and collaboration with patients and colleagues.

Effective communication
  • Listen to patients and answer any questions honestly
  • Ensure that information is delivered in a manner that can be understood. Identify and apply practical measures to overcome any communication and language barriers
  • Provide support and information to patients' relatives or carers in a considerate manner
  • Doctors on duty need to be easily reachable by their patients and colleagues for any advice or support

Partnership with patients
  • Empower patients with the information required for patients to make decisions with regards to their care. This includes information on the clinical conditions, treatment options and the relevant risks and uncertainties
  • Ensure that patients are aware of the progress of their care
  • The roles and responsibilities of each member of the team need to be made clear to the patients
  • Patient confidentiality needs to be maintained, even after the patient is deceased

Fair and respectful care of all patients
  • Respect patients' dignity and privacy
  • Respect any health, cultural and religious beliefs held by the patients, even if they do not agree with yours.

If you have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure e.g. abortion, you need to:
  • Inform the patient that they have the right to see another practitioner
  • Provide the necessary information and support towards the patient seeking another doctor. In doing so, refrain from expressing disapproval of the patient's lifestyle, choices or beliefs
  • Find another doctor to substitute you if it is not practical for the patient to arrange to see another doctor

Partnership with colleagues
  • Doctors are expected to work in a team in a manner that serves patients' best interest
  • It is important to respect the skills and contributions of every member of the team and be fair to every member of the team
  • Understand that your actions may affect others within and outside the team
  • It is your duty to complete any post that you have formally accepted as leaving the post assigned to you may compromise patient safety especially if this creates a gap in the medical rota
  • Unless the trust has a reasonable time to make adjustments, it is important that you work the hours required of your contract before leaving a job

Coordination of care between healthcare providers and between health and social care providers. This include
  • Providing all relevant information to all clinicians or social care providers involved in the care of the patients
  • Checking that a named doctor or team has taken over the care
  • Ensure that the clinician filling in for you or taking over the care is appropriately trained to provide safe care for the patient

The Good Medical Practice also made statements with regards to Doctors as teachers. It recommends that doctors support the training and teaching of junior staff members and medical students*. This includes
  • Ensuring adequate supervision
  • Writing honest feedback/references/appraisals on their competence, performance and conduct
  • Being a mentor
  • Supporting those who are struggling with their performance or health

*In all circumstances, patient safety needs to be prioritised

options: Ask the boyfriend to step outside briefly, so that you can speak to the girl alone and assess capacity, what she wants, and the nature of their relationship
Involve a consultant
Involve social services
Call the girl's mother and ask for her opinion
Refer for termination as she is above the age of consent
questions:
A 16-year-old girl presents to the Emergency Department with her 27-year-old boyfriend, requesting a termination of pregnancy. The girl seems anxious and isn't saying much or making eye contact, and her boyfriend is doing most of the talking. He seems angry and keen to 'get this over and done with quickly and quietly'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes: Although the girl is old enough to make her own decisions if deemed to have capacity, the nature of the presentation warrants further investigation (1) before discharge as the patient may be at risk. If this is not possible, a consultant may need to be involved (2). Calling social services at this point would be inappropriate as not enough is known, although they may be able to give some much needed guidance as to how to proceed (3). It is true that the patient is old enough to consent(5), but it is important in order to be a good doctor not to simply judge based off numbers and rules, an analysis of the situation at hand is imperative. If the girl is deemed Gillick competent, calling her mother (4) is not only inappropriate, but breeches patient confidentiality. Doing so could ruin not only the patient-doctor relationship, but also the girls relationship with her mother.

options: Cancel the prescription and re-prescribe the paracetamol at the recommended dose
Report your colleague to the GMC
Tell the nurse that the FY2 who prescribed the medication should change the prescription
Fill out an incident form
Inform your colleague of the prescription error
questions:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working in paediatrics. A nurse approaches you and asks you to check a prescription. Your FY2 colleague has prescribed paracetamol for a 5-year-old girl, but they have prescribed the adult dose, which is much higher than the recommended dose for this patient. Your colleague is currently on their lunch break.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes: This question looks at the prescribing errors and patient safety. In this scenario, we have a paracetamol prescription for a patient that is considerably higher than the recommended dose. The most appropriate action would be to cancel the prescription and re-prescribe the paracetamol at the recommended dose (A) - this prevents any harm from coming to the patient and allows the nurse to administer the drug in a timely manner. Given that this is a considerable prescribing error, you should also inform your colleague of the prescription error (E). An incident form can be completed to highlight the issues around prescribing for paediatric patients. However, this is not an immediate action that needs to be taken and can happen after amending the paracetamol prescription. Telling the nurse that the FY2 who prescribed the medication should change the prescription (C) is inappropriate and unprofessional. Your colleague is currently on their break, and waiting for them to come back to change the prescription causes an unnecessary delay for the patient to receive their paracetamol. The least appropriate option is to report your colleague to the GMC (B) - this is an honest mistake and can be handled internally.

options: Disclose the information to the girlfriend only after obtaining consent from the patient
Encourage him to tell his girlfriend
Accept that his transmission risk will be low if using condoms and taking antiretroviral medication
Inform the patient that you will disclose this information to his girlfriend with or without his consent
Disclose the information to the girlfriend without informing the patient
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in a GUM clinic. A 25-year-old gentleman has returned for HIV counselling. He tells you that the last doctor informed him that he must disclose his HIV status to his girlfriend, but that he has decided he is not going to tell her. He says that he plans to start treatment and that they use condoms, so it will not be passed on.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
In the case of serious communicable disease, you may break confidentiality if you consider the risk to an individual or the public outweighs the benefits of maintaining confidentiality. You should of course attempt to convince him to disclose the information himself in the first instance, as it saves you from having to break confidentiality. However, if he refuses and you consider there is a risk of serious harm to his girlfriend, and there are no less intrusive means of protecting her, then this is a situation in which you can break confidentiality. However, as in any situation in which you need to break confidentiality, you should ideally tell the patient that you plan to do so.

Other factors to consider when deciding whether or not to break confidentiality include: the distress/harm caused to the patient by disclosing, the harm in trust in doctors generally, the harm to an individual or the public, if harms can be avoiding whilst maintaining confidentiality, or if not, the least intrusive option.

In this scenario, although theoretically the risk of transmission would be low if they use condoms and his viral low becomes undetectable with treatment, there is a chance that he may still put his partner at risk, therefore C is the worst option.

title: GMC guidance: Confidentiality
body:
The UK General Medical Council (GMC) provides guidelines on confidentiality to help doctors maintain trust with their patients and respect their right to privacy. Here is a summary of the key principles in GMC's guidance on confidentiality:
  • Patients' right to privacy: Doctors must respect patients' right to privacy and should not disclose their personal information without consent, unless required by law or justified by the public interest.
  • Obtaining consent: Whenever possible, doctors should obtain explicit consent from patients before disclosing their information. The consent should be informed and given freely, and patients should understand the potential consequences of sharing their information.
  • Anonymization: When using patient information for purposes such as teaching, research, or quality improvement, doctors should anonymize the data whenever possible to protect patients' identities.
  • Disclosures in the public interest: In exceptional circumstances, doctors may disclose patient information without consent if it is in the public interest, such as to prevent serious harm to others or in response to communicable diseases that pose a risk to public health.
  • Legal requirements: Doctors must comply with legal requirements to disclose patient information, such as court orders or statutory reporting obligations.
  • Confidentiality after death: Doctors should continue to respect patients' confidentiality even after their death, unless there are compelling reasons to disclose information.
  • Sharing information with the healthcare team: Doctors may share patient information within the healthcare team on a need-to-know basis to provide safe and effective care.
  • Record-keeping: Doctors should maintain accurate, up-to-date, and secure records to protect patient information and ensure its confidentiality.
  • Communicating with patients: Doctors should communicate openly and honestly with patients about their right to confidentiality and how their information may be used.
  • Working with third parties: When working with third parties, such as insurers or employers, doctors should ensure that they have appropriate consent from patients before sharing their information.

options: Take no action to avoid inflaming the situation
Go and discuss his concerns with the patient
Ask the other patients on the ward to speak to the patient to give him reassurance that you are spending your time equally
Inform him of the patient advice and liaison service (PALS)
Offer to the patient that he can discuss his concerns with a senior member of the ward team
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a gastroenterology ward. The nurses inform you that a 50-year-old male patient is angry and wants to make a complaint against you as they feel you haven't been spending as much time with them as they think you should.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
On the face of it this may seem a spurious complaint but it's important to take any concerns from a patient seriously.

The first and best step is to speak to the patient directly yourself (B). Following this, another senior member of the ward team (E) may be able to resolve the complaint locally.

If you can't deal with the issue locally then you should involve the PALS service (D) to try and help deal with the patients concerns.

Ignoring the situation (A) is never a good answer.

Involving other patients (C) is wrong for many reasons, not least confidentiality.

Request a period of shadowing with the current junior doctor
Speak with your close family
Do nothing
Send your concerns in an email to the Foundation school
questions:
You are a junior doctor about to commence working on a coronary care unit in 3 weeks' time. You have lots of concerns regarding the responsibilities of the job, and thus are nervous and not looking forward to starting the job. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Effectively preparing for a stressful and intense job is the only way to ensure you are mentally prepared for it. If you do not do this, your mental health could deteriorate. Obtaining advice and practical experience from shadowing will be the only effective ways to prepare for the job and learn exactly what you will have to do and be responsible for. These are therefore the best options.

Reading your finals notes and practising clinical skills are both good ideas before you start your new job, but are unlikely to give you any information on what being an FY2 is like. Speaking with family may help to put your mind at rest but again is unlikely to help practically.

The Foundation School may be able to send some written information about the job but it will not be as helpful as hands-on practical experience and talking to those who currently do the job. Doing nothing in this situation is useless.

title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013
concept: You must be sure that you are mentally and physically well enough to work and declare anything that might pose a problem

options: After the consultation explain to the medical student that his actions were inappropriate
Apologise to the patient
Ask the medical student to explain to the patient why he believes the drug to be more effective
Prescribe the medication that the medical student has recommended
Review the journal and evidence of the new drug
questions:
You are the doctor working in the care of the elderly ward. You are being shadowed by a medical student. You are seeing a patient on the ward round, and you advise the patient that you will start them on a new medication. The medical student interrupts and advises that there is a more effective medicine that he had read about in a journal. The patient looks distressed by what has happened.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
This question is focused on good communication with a colleague and maintaining patient trust. This is highlighted in the GMC Good Medical Practice's - Communication, Partnership and Teamwork domain, and the Maintaining Trust domain. This GMC guidance specifically advises: 'You must be open and honest with patients if things go wrong. If a patient under your care has suffered harm or distress, you should: put matters right (if that is possible), and offer an apology'.

Apologising to the patient is the most appropriate action as it is important to acknowledge when mistakes occur in clinical practice. The patient is clearly distressed and thus needs reassurance. Apologising is in the best interest of maintaining trust in you as a doctor and in the profession as a whole.

After the consultation it would be important to explain to the medical student that his actions were inappropriate. Providing honest feedback should allow the medical student to reflect on his inappropriate behaviour in order to prevent further lapses in judgment from occurring again in the future.

Reviewing the journal and evidence of the new drug is a somewhat appropriate action. There may be good evidence for use of this new drug. However local policies should only be deviated from by a senior doctor.

Asking the medical student to explain to the patient why he believes the drug to be more effective is entirely inappropriate as it is asking the medical student to perform a task which is outside his scope of practice as a student. This could have multiple adverse effects including patient safety and loss of trust in the profession.

Prescribing the medication that the medical student has recommended is entirely inappropriate and is a significant patient safety risk.

title: GMC: Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues
body:
As with all aspects of medicine, the fundamental principle remains the same; make the patient your first concern. The purpose of this guidance is to allow the effective functioning of the clinical team to allow patient care to be done safely and smoothly, to the highest standards.

Leadership

The recommendations on leadership emphasise the importance of working within a multidisciplinary team. They specifically mention that other team members in leadership positions must be respected. This respect for non-medical staff in leadership roles is important.

For example, respecting the advice and leadership of an infection control nurse with regard to hand hygiene is important in making patients are protected from iatrogenic pathogen spread.

Respect for colleagues

If a colleague feels like they are not respected and not valued they may not feel able to speak up if they have concerns which may be relevant to patient safety. This is particularly important for junior and non-medical staff, and so it especially important to respect and value their skills and contribution to the team.

Additionally there is both a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that your colleagues have a safe and fair workplace. All doctors are responsible for facilitating this not only to avoid unpleasant behaviour themselves, but also by challenging others who act in a bullying or discriminatory manner. This is important both to comply with laws and policies on equality and diversity, but also to ensure patient safety as bullying and harassment will impair team cohesion and communication.


Communication within and between teams

The key message from this part of the guidance is that it is important that it is clear who is responsible for communicating what information both within members of the team, to other teams, and also to patients and carers. Mistakes are often made when team members assume that someone else will have passed on the relevant information and no one ends up doing it. Therefore whenever there is any doubt about whose job it is to pass on certain information, it is obligatory to check.

For example, if you expect that the nursing staff would have told you about any allergies the patient has, before prescribing it would be important to confirm with them that they have handed over all the relevant information.

Also it is important that teams cooperate more generally, including by having handovers. Proactive steps must be taken to clarify responsibilities and improve communication.

Responsibility and accountability

The most important duty of a doctor is to the dignity, safety and care of their patients. Again, it is important for doctors to ensure that it is clear exactly which staff members have which responsibilities, to ensure that these do not 'fall between the cracks' and get missed.

It is also important that you make these responsibilities clear to any staff in a team that you are leading.

When mistakes happen, it's often the result of system problems. For example it could be under-staffing putting decision making under higher strain, causing more mistakes. This happened in the Bawa-Garba case, the tragic death of a child from unrecognised sepsis on a day where a single doctor was trying to cover multiple wards.

Consequently, it is also the responsibility of doctors to engage in setting up and maintaining systems to make sure that risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Doctors are just as accountable for advice they give as a member of a decision making body, as they are for any other medical advice they offer.
